intro: Pseudogynoxys sonchoides, commonly known as the Mexican dandelion, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows as an annual herb with a hairy stem and lobed leaves. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in the spring and summer, followed by the production of parachute-like seeds. Pseudogynoxys sonchoides is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
